results.title: Melbourne: festival city
results.creator_credit: Gordon C. Lloyd, Tourist Development Authority of Victoria and Cinesound
results.brief_description: Melbourne’s Moomba festival - the city comes alive with processions, regattas, the Herald open air art show, music under the stars at the Myer Music Bowl, and the crowning of the Moomba Queen. The film also shows some of the Melbourne landscape and the background of daily life; Melbourne’s economic expansion; the Melbourne Cup, the race for which the nation stands still; Australian Rules Football, drawing crowds of over 50,000; fine golf courses; hunting; night life. It closes with a coverage of the Moomba procession, with all its varied floats, including the Bunyip and the Chinese dragon.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gordon C. Lloyd, Tourist Development Authority of Victoria and Cinesound

results.title: The Poetry Cup
results.creator_credit: Terrence Doran, Ken Smeaton and Peter Lane
results.brief_description: The inaugural Poetry Cup was filmed in September at the Rochester Castle Hotel, Fitzroy as part of the 1989 Spoleto Fringe Festival. Just as the comedy resurgence began in the small cafes and clubs before moving to a wider television audience so then the poets. These people are performers with an emphasis on entertainment. No quiet reads here, but full blooded performance poetry. Their skills have been honed amid beer, smoke, pool players and football, in the back rooms of inner city hotels such as the Provincial, the Rochester, the Leicester Arms and cafes, prisons, schools and the streets.

results.title: Blue like an orange
results.brief_description: Puppets of the Orient and the Occident are presented in this UNESCO contribution to understanding between East and West. Scenes of puppet plays in India, Japan, Singapore, Malaysia, Laos, Poland, Czechoslovakia and the United States today. The presentations illustrate the great variety of the traditions which have survived for thousands of years. Also includes archival footage of Jim Henson and “the muppets” including a very early Kermit.

results.title: Another day
results.creator_credit: Anti Cancer Council, Jennie Blackwood and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: Views of a number of people who have suffered from cancer leading normal happy lives. Stresses the importance of seeking medical advice and aid at the first suspicion that one has contracted the disease.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 3 [1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival]
results.creator_credit: Michael Costello, David McLauchlan and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description:
Documents the 1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival Parade and the Fringe Furniture Exhibition, including interviews with Virginia Hyam, Fringe Director, and Axel, Fringe Furniture Co-ordinator. The Melbourne Fringe Festival has become an institution since its inception in 1982 when a small group of independent artists gathered together to create a platform to present new and independent art to the community. From those early beginnings the Melbourne-based festival now attracts interstate and international guests and covers a wide variety of arts
performances including outdoor events such as the Annual Parade in Brunswick Street, Fitzroy, the Annual Waiter’s Race, street-theatre and live bands and indoor events including comedy and cabaret, music and theatre. The Fringe Furniture Exhibition allows for young students
and designers an opportunity to show-off their creative ability and caters for non-mainstream pieces. Crazy, outrageous, quirky and even occasionally practical, the Exhibition contains an amazing selection of eclectic pieces as witnessed in this documentary program.
Reporters: Melissa Iaria and Phillip Taylor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Costello, David McLauchlan and Northern Access TV

results.title: Ice Age
results.creator_credit: Lori Forte, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Blue Sky Studios and Chris Wedge
results.brief_description: Ice Age is set 20,000 years ago, amidst the time of Neanderthals and pre-historic animals. As thousands of creatures head south, away from the ice and freezing cold, three turn north, in an unlikely quest to save a human baby.

constellations_other.name: Make it cute, make them think
constellations_other.description: Cartoons and anime are known for their dynamic and vibrant visuals, but beneath the cuteness they can also deliver powerful environmental messages and address the climate crisis.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Lori Forte, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Blue Sky Studios and Chris Wedge
results.description: Ice age is set 20,000 years ago, amidst the time of Neanderthals and pre-historic animals. As thousands of creatures head south, away from the ice and freezing cold, three turn north, in an unlikely quest to save a human baby. The team consist of Manny, a depressed and kindly woolly mammoth; a sabre-toothed tiger named Diego; and Sid, a chatty sloth. Together these three battle volcanoes, predators and each other to rescue a child’s life, which ironically represents for them a future predator. With some truly wonderful set pieces, the animators of “Ice age” have created quite a magical netherworld where the dodo bird is depicted as too dim to ensure its survival into the next age and a persistent squirrel assiduously attempts to salvage a single acorn for a future feed. “Ice age” is very much family entertainment and should also prove interesting to those tracking the developments of computer animation. Humorously written, if at times a little twee, the film is a parable about friendship, acceptance and banding together. Featuring the voices of John Leguizamo, Ray Romano, Denis Leary, Jack Black and Jane Krakowski.
description_for_label: Ice age is set 20,000 years ago, amidst the time of Neanderthals and pre-historic animals. Humorously written, if at times a little twee, the film is a parable about friendship, acceptance and banding together. Featuring the voices of John Leguizamo, Ray Romano, Denis Leary, Jack Black and Jane Krakowski.

results.title: Access Video 1973-1982
results.creator_credit: Helen Eisler and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
The results of a reserach project funded by the Australian Film Commission and the Commonwealth Employment Programme this title presents highlights of programmes of historical importance, demonstrating the growth and maturing of independent video which in turn reflects the development of community and political activity during the seventies.

During this decade 12 access video centres were established. This title shows highlights of proigrammes made by various centres.

results.title: Here's your bike, Ed!
results.creator_credit: John Taylor, Steve Westh, Taylormade Films and Vic Roads
results.brief_description: The purpose of this title is to demonstrate a variety of skills that children need to cycle safely on roads. Designed to accompany a Bike Ed program in schools, with Teacher’s notes, there are a variety of activities and drills which will develop children’s confidence as bike riders and users of the road.

results.title: Blood
results.brief_description:
Travelling through Australia with his film camera, Ivan Sen has visited many Aboriginal communities, from urban to prison to distant-rural. Photographing people in their definitive environments, he has created an installation which is a subtle and deeply moving meditation on skin, landscape, gesture and the many nuances of Aboriginal identities.

The work contains imagery of people who have all shared the same blood. The blood of the Gamilaroi people of Northern NSW.

results.title: Lo-Arna 1981
results.creator_credit: Bob Weis, Geoffrey Nottage, Channel 0\28 and Generation Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Women of the sun (A)”.
Part Four of the “Women of the Sun” series which presents events that occurred to four different aboriginal women, at different periods in time. This episode is set in 1981 and examines the inner turmoil and insecurity of an 18 year old girl when her adoptive parents tell her she is not of French Polynesian descent, but is the daughter of an Aboriginal woman.
